block.p: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Westchester and Putnam counties this week. Items for the guide may be submitted by mail, at least three weeks in advance, to Westchester Cultural Calendar, North Salem, N.Y. 10560.
MUSIC
Theater

CROTON FALLS -- ''Abundance'' by Beth Henley. Today at 4 p.m., Thursday through next Saturday at 8 p.m. and next Sunday at 4 p.m. Tickets: $17; Thursday evening only, $14. The Schoolhouse, Owens Road. 277-8477.

An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Westchester and Putnam counties this week. Items for the guide may be submitted by mail, at least three weeks in advance, to Westchester Cultural Calendar, North Salem, N.Y. 10560.
MUSIC
Theater

CROTON FALLS -- ''Abundance'' by Beth Henley. Today at 4 p.m., Thursday through next Saturday at 8 p.m. and next Sunday at 4 p.m. Tickets: $17; Thursday evening only, $14. The Schoolhouse, Owens Road. 277-8477.

ELMSFORD -- ''Bosom Buddies and Baggy Pants,'' show with popular routines from vaudeville and burlesque. Tuesday at 1 p.m., with lunch at 11:30 a.m. Tickets: $46. Tuesday at 8 p.m., with dinner at 6. Tickets: $55. The musical ''Grease.'' Wednesdays through Saturdays at 8 p.m., with dinner at 6 and Sundays at 7 p.m., with dinner at 5. Matinees: Wednesdays and Thursdays at 1 p.m., with lunch at 11:30 a.m. and Sundays at 1:30 p.m., with lunch at noon. Through June 24. Tickets: $46 to $66, with discounts at selected performances for students, older people and children. Westchester Broadway Theater, 1 Broadway Plaza. 592-2222.

KATONAH -- Axial Theater, presenting three one-act plays: ''Tina Hits the Troposphere'' by Bill D'Agostino; ''Beyond Easton'' by Emily Masciandaro and ''Persephone Rising'' by Howard Meyer. Friday and next Saturday at 8 p.m. and next Sunday at 7 p.m. Tickets: $10. Barnspace, 113 Todd Road. 232-2034.

MAMARONECK -- ''Forbidden Broadway Cleans Up Its Act!'' Lightning-paced musical, lampooning America's most talked about stars and shows, starring Diana Sheehan. Today at 2 and 7 p.m. Tickets: $28; matinee, $23; members, $15. (Tickets for series subscription, including ''The Mysterious Mr. Love'' from July 13 through July 23 and ''A Couple of Blaguards'' from July 28 through July 30, $65; matinee subscription, $50.) Comedy by Robert Klein. Next Saturday at 7 and 9:30 p.m. Tickets: $25; members, $15. Emelin Theater, Library Lane. 698-0098.

MONTROSE -- Hand-to-Mouth Players perform ''Painting Churches'' by Tina Howe. Next Friday and Saturday at 8 p.m. and next Sunday at 2 p.m. Through June 17. Tickets: $10; students and people 62 and older, $8. Theater of Building 2, Veterans Affairs Hospital, Route 9A. 734-4336.

PURCHASE -- Play Group Theater for Children and Young Adults present ''Bridge to Terabithia,'' a musical based on the book by Katherine Paterson. Next Sunday and June 18 at 1 and 7 p.m. Tickets: $15; students and older people, $12; children, $10. Little Theater of Manhattanville College. 946-0649.

SLEEPY HOLLOW -- ''The Fire This Time,'' based on an 18th-century New York Supreme Court trial, of a slave tried for arson and conspiracy. Next Saturday at 7 p.m. Tickets: $8; people 60 and older, $7; children 5 through 17, $4. Old Dutch Church of Sleepy Hollow. 631-8200, ext. 628.
Music and Dance

ARDSLEY -- Swing dance and Salsa lessons for single people 30 and older. Presented by Greenburgh Singles. Tuesday at 7:30 to 8:30 p.m. Tickets: $10. Registration. Anthony F. Veteran Park. 693-8985, ext. 157.

CHAPPAQUA -- Debut of the Concert Artists of Chappaqua: Setsuko Nagata and Kikuei Ikeda, violinists; Bernard Rose, pianist, and Clive Greensmith, cellist, perform works by Mozart and Faure. Benefiting Chappaqua Chamber Orchestra. Today at 3 p.m. Tickets: $75. New Castle Community Center, 10 Center Street. 238-1373.

CHAPPAQUA -- Joachim Piano Trio: Helene Jeanney, pianist; Deborah Molodofsky, violinist, and Ariane Lallemand, cellist, perform works by Schubert and Mozart. Presented in a private home by Amadeus Conservatory of Music. Next Sunday at 4 p.m. Tickets: $20. Reservations. 238-0388.
CROSS RIVER -- Westchester/Putnam Youth String Symphony perform works by Mozart, Telemann, Debussy and others. Today at 3 p.m. Donation: $6; students and older people, $3. John Jay Middle School.

MAMARONECK -- Pamela Frank and Alexander Simionescu, violinists; Peter Wiley, cellist, and Gary Graffman, pianist, perform works by Prokofiev, Kodaly and Korngold. Presented in a private home by Performers of Westchester. Today at 4 p.m. Tickets: $20. Reservations. 693-9658.

MOUNT KISCO -- ''For the Spirit,'' the Cantemus Singers perform sacred music by Vivaldi, Brahms, Handel and Andrew Lloyd Weber; Jena Smith, conductor. Today at 4 p.m. Free. St. Francis of Assisi Roman Catholic Church, Main Street.

MOUNT VERNON -- Pre-Bayou Festival bash, with three bands, free T-shirt and CD and free ticket to the Bayou Festival at Croton Point Park in August. Tomorrow from 8 to 11 p.m. Tickets: $69. Concert by vocalist, Ann Rabson, of the Uppity Blues Women. Friday at 11 p.m. Cover charge: $10. Bayou Restaurant, 580 Gramatan Avenue. 668-2634.

PAWLING -- Concert by the band Boneheads, with Gandalf Murphy and the Slambovian Circus of Dreams. Tonight at 8. Tickets: $20; members, $17.50. Contemporary music by Eric Tingstad, guitarist, and Nancy Rumbel, oboist, English hornist and on double ocarina, and Robin Spielberg, pianist and composer. Thursday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $20; members, $17.50. American Celtic music band, Clandestine. Friday at 9 p.m. Tickets: $17.50; members, $15. Singer, songwriter and musician, Colin Hay, and guest artist, Janet Robin. Next Saturday at 9 p.m. Tickets: $20; members, $17.50. Towne Crier Cafe, 130 Route 22. 855-1300.

TARRYTOWN -- ''Spirit, Stong and Song,'' concert based on the healing power of music by Sandi Kimmel. Next Saturday at 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $5. United Methodist Church, 27 South Washington Street. 631-5809.
YONKERS -- Jimmy Hill Jazz Quartet. Today at noon. Free. Bronx River Parkway Reservation, Scarsdale Road. 242-7275.
Art
HARRISON -- Exhibition of art by Grace Powers Fraioli. Through June. Reception next Saturday from 2 to 4 p.m. Harrison Public Library, Bruce Avenue. 835-0324.

LARCHMONT -- Watercolors by Rieko Oniki. Reception next Saturday from 3 to 4:30 p.m. Photographs of Ireland and Italy by Kevin McDevitt and terra cotta and stone sculpture by Judith Litt. Also on view through June 28. Larchmont Public Library, 121 Larchmont Avenue. 834-2281.

MAHOPAC -- Juried theme show titled ''Faces: In Life, In Nature, In Your Imagination'' and ''Chicken Soup for the Eyes,'' cartoons by David Jacobson and Matt Davies. Through next Sunday. Putnam Arts Council's Levine Art Center, 255 Kennicut Hill Road. 628-3664.

NEW ROCHELLE -- ''Westchester Biennial 2000,'' including photography by Renata Rainer, sculpture by Grace Powers, video installation by Yechiam Gal and Rosalind Schneider and works on paper by Marcy B. Freedman. Through next Sunday. Castle Gallery, College of New Rochelle. 654-5235.
NEW ROCHELLE -- New Rochelle Art Association's Jules Bauer award show. Opens next Saturday. Through June 24. New Rochelle Public Library, Library Plaza. 632-7878

PEEKSKILL -- ''Floating Dialogues: Imagery and Abstraction,'' with works by Dana DeVito, Sergio Gonzalez-Tornero, Tom Halsall, Erik Hanson, William C. Maxwell, Julie Overskei and Tedd Stratis. Opening reception next Saturday from 1 to 3 p.m. Through July 29. Paramount Center, 1008 Brown Street. 739-2333.
PEEKSKILL -- ''River Rhythms,'' river collages by Susan MacMurdy. Through June 25. Reception next Saturday from 1 to 5 p.m. Flat Iron Gallery, 105 South Division Street. 734-1894.
PELHAM -- ''Family Ties,'' exhibition turning artists' family experiences into universal and collective storytelling. Through next Saturday. Pelham Art Center, 155 Fifth Avenue. 738-2525.
PORT CHESTER -- Sculpture, pottery and ceramic works by students of center. Opening reception today from 2 to 4 p.m. Through June 17. Clay Art Center, 40 Beech Street. 937-2047.

PURCHASE -- ''Whitfield Lovell: Portrayals,'' ''Welded! Sculpture of the 20th Century,'' ''Carol Hamoy: Portraits of the Artists as Young Girls,'' ''Recent Acquisitions: Gifts From the Lawrence Gussman Collection of African Art,'' ''Selections From the Roy R. Neuberger Collection,'' ''Object and Intellect: African Art From the Permanent Collection'' and ''Ancient Civilizations: The Roy R. Neuberger Collection.'' Museum's hours: Tuesdays through Fridays from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. and Saturdays and Sundays from 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $4; students and people 62 and older, $2; children, free. (Helene Brandt discusses her art in the exhibition ''Welded!'' Wednesday at noon. Free with museum admission. Bring lunch or buy lunch in the museum cafe.) Neuberger Museum of Art, Purchase College. 251-6100.

WHITE PLAINS -- ''Westchester in the Movies,'' photographs and posters celebrating filmmaking in Westchester, from 1910 to the present; with vintage pictures from the productions of director, D. W. Griffith. Through Labor Day. Museum Gallery of White Plains Public Library, 100 Martine Avenue. 422-1480.
YONKERS -- Paintings and poems by Meg Lindsay. Through Aug. 16. Sarah Lawrence College library. 337-0700.
Lectures

MAMARONECK -- Gerald T. Koeppel discusses his book ''Water for Gotham,'' of the struggle to find clean water for Manhattan and the building of the Croton Aqueduct. Presented by the Friends of Mamaroneck Library. Wednesday at 8 p.m. Free. Emelin Theater, Library Lane. 698-0098.

OSSINING -- Ted Conover discusses his latest book ''Newjack: Guarding Sing Sing,'' about his year spent as a correction officer at the prison. Tuesday at 7:30 p.m. Free. Ossining Public Library, 53 Croton Avenue. 941-2416.

OSSINING -- Leah Waybright Kennell talks of ''Beauty Gone Wild,'' her book featuring original music and commentary about 12 flowers. Thursday from 7:30 to 8:30 p.m. Free. Teatown Lake Reservation, 1600 Spring Valley Rd. 762-2912.

PEEKSKILL -- Samuel G. White, descendant of architect, Sanford White presents a slide show on the history of the architectural firm, McKim, Mead and White. Today at 2 p.m. Free. Knights of Columbus Building, Union Avenue. (Followed by reception at the Peekskill Museum, 124 Union Avenue.) 736-0473.
SLEEPY HOLLOW -- Jane Cooper and Susan Pliner read selections of their poetry. Today at 4:30 p.m. Donation: $5; members, $3. Hudson Valley Writers Center, 300 Riverside Drive. 332-5953.

WHITE PLAINS -- Dr. Arthur B. Zelman, medical director for the Center for Preventive Psychiatry, discusses medicating children for behavioral and emotional problems. Wednesday at noon to 1:30 p.m. Bring lunch. 949-7680. Panel discussion on how your small business can utilize and adapt to the Internet. Next Saturday from 9:15 a.m. to noon. 422-1480. Both free. White Plains Public Library, 100 Martine Avenue.
Films
NEW ROCHELLE -- ''Dancing at Lughnasa.'' Thursday at 7:30 p.m. Donation: $2. New Rochelle Public Library. 632-7878.
PEEKSKILL -- ''East Is East.'' Thursday and Friday at 8 p.m. $9. Paramount Center, 1008 Brown Street. 739-2333.
WHITE PLAINS -- D. W. Griffith's 1924 silent film classic ''America,'' filmed in Westchester and starring Lionel Barrymore. Tomorrow at 2 and 6:30 p.m. Free. White Plains Public Library. 422-1480.
Children
ELMSFORD -- ''Charlotte's Web,'' musical performed by Westco Productions. Next Saturday and June 17 at 11 a.m. and 1 and 3 p.m. Tickets: $12, show only. Westchester Broadway Theater. 592-2222.

GREENBURGH -- Family fair with food, jewelry, crafts, hands-on craft activities, entertainment, games, rides and nature activities for all ages. Next Saturday at noon to 4:30 p.m. Admission: $4; members, $2. Greenburgh Nature Center, Dromore Road. 723-3470.

NEW ROCHELLE -- ''Viva Mexico in New Rochelle,'' featuring stories, music and dancing, a Spanish book fair and pinata-making workshop. Today from 1 to 4 p.m. Free. New Rochelle Public Library, Library Plaza. 632-7878.

PURCHASE -- ''Heavy Metal Arts Festival,'' presented in conjunction with the current art exhibition ''Welded! Sculpture of the 20th century.'' Family members make sculptures using recycled objects and create musical instruments from tossed-out materials. Next Sunday at noon to 4 p.m., with steel drum concerts by Nu-Lite Band at 1 and 2. Admission: $5; free for children 2 and younger. Neuberger Museum of Art, Purchase College. 251-6100.

RYE -- Playland Park features amusement rides for adults and young children, a boardwalk, boating, miniature golf, arcades, beach and more. Park's hours through June 23: Wednesdays and Thursdays from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m., Fridays from 10 a.m. to midnight, Saturdays from noon to midnight and Sundays from noon to 11 p.m. Free admission. Tickets: 75 cents each; 12-ticket book, $8; 24-ticket book, $15; 36-ticket book, $19. (Rides are three to five tickets each.) Parking: weekdays,$4; Saturdays and Sundays, $5; holidays, $7. Exit 19 of I-95. 925-2700.
TARRYTOWN -- Children's concert by Red Grammer. Presented by Hudson Valley Writers Center. Next Saturday at 2 p.m. Free. Patriots Park. 332-5953.

WHITE PLAINS -- Children's book author, Campbell Geeslin, and illustrator, Robert Casilla, talk about their work and read selections from their books. Program for children 6 and older and their families. Tuesday at 7 p.m. Free. White Plains Public Library, 100 Martine Avenue. 422-1480.

WHITE PLAINS -- Slam dunk basketball camp, for children 8 through 14. Sponsored by Westchester County Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation. July 10 through July 14 and July 24 through July 28 from 9:30 a.m. to 3:30 p.m. Cost: $250 a week; $200 with registration and payment by Friday. County Center. 242-6352.

YONKERS -- ''Fun Flubber and Other Cool Creations,'' science experiments with Steve Ruff. Today at 1:30 p.m. Cost: $1 and museum admission additional $4; people 62 and older and children, $3. ''Sky Tonight,'' sky show for children 8 and older and adults. Fridays at 7 p.m. Free tickets available at museum's front desk beginning at 6:30. Hudson River Museum, 511 Warburton Avenue. 963-4550.
Potpourri

BRONX PARK -- Award-Winning Roses Week, with tips and tours at the Peggy Rockefeller rose garden, featuring 2,700 rose plants. Garden experts on hand to answer questions. Today and next Saturday and Sunday from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. Guided tours. Wednesday through Friday at 1 p.m. Performances of the rose in music and madrigals by an early music ensemble. Today and next Saturday and Sunday from 1 to 4 p.m. Chinese garden and peony show at the Enid A. Haupt Conservatory. Closes today. Garden's hours: Tuesdays through Sundays and Monday holidays at 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. (718) 817-8700.

CHAPPAQUA -- Chappaqua outdoor antiques show with 70 dealers and Andrew Paoletti offering free Oriental rug appraisals and tips on cleaning and preserving them. Benefiting the Arts Council of New Castle. Today from 10 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. Admission: $4. Railroad Station Plaza, off exit 32 of Saw Mill River Parkway.

CHAPPAQUA -- Annual book sale sponsored by the Friends of the Chappaqua Library. Thursday from 10 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Friday and Saturday, from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. at the library at 195 South Greeley Avenue. On Sunday, from 1 to 3 p.m., the remaining books are free. 238-4779, ext. 2.

GARRISON -- Snapping turtle walk. Observe female snapping turtles crawling up the steep bank from their habitat in Constitution Marsh to lay their eggs. Next Saturday at 7:30 a.m., with coffee and doughnuts at 7. Tickets: $8; children 6 through 14, $5. Reservations. Boscobel Restoration, 1601 Route 9D. 265-3638, ext. 115.

LARCHMONT -- ''Creating Your Garden,'' hands-on advice at a local garden, with tips about creating a beautiful garden under almost any conditions. Presented by Larchmont-Mamaroneck Center for Continuing Education. Tuesday from 10 a.m. to noon. $20. Registration. 698-9126.

MONTROSE -- Learn how to retell family stories at a workshop led by Gerald Fierst. Presented by Croton/Cortlandt Center for the Arts. Next Saturday from 2 to 4 p.m. Registration. Followed an evening of storytelling by Carol Birch. Next Saturday from 7 to 8 p.m. Both are free. Hendrick Hudson Library, 185 Kings Ferry Road. 739-5654.

NEW ROCHELLE -- Thomas Paine Day, with Robert Merrill singing the national anthem, performing artists, military color guard, readings of Paine's work, Revolutionary War re-enactment and cannon salute, tours and refreshments. Today at 2 p.m. Thomas Paine Historic Site, 983 North Avenue. 632-5376.

NEW ROCHELLE -- ''Take Charge! Career and Life Planning After 50.'' Seven-week workshop (with an orientation session and an individual session with a career counselor), focusing on work, volunteerism, entrepreneurial ventures and leisure opportunities. Presented by Westchester Library System. June 12 from 7 to 9 p.m. Free. Registration. New Rochelle Public Library. 674-3612.

NORTH SALEM -- Championship rodeo. Sponsored by North Salem Free Library and Croton Falls Fire Department. Next Saturday at 2 p.m. and next Sunday at 1 p.m. Tickets: $12; children, $9; advance tickets, $2 less. Old Salem Farm, Route 124 (June Road). 669-5161.
OSSINING -- Butterfly hike for adults, led by Charlie Roberto. Next Sunday from 10 a.m. to noon. (Slide presentation if raining.) Free. Registration. Teatown Lake Reservation. 762-2912.
PURCHASE -- Vassar book sale, with sale of 30,000 hard covers and paperbacks. Friday through next Sunday from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Free. Purchase College. 946-1924.

RYE -- Rye Historical Society open house, with gallery talk of the new exhibit ''Hats from the Square House Museum Collection.'' Next Saturday at 2:15 p.m., followed by ''Punch Van Winkle,'' a Punch-and-Judy puppet show by Fred Greenspan at 3 p.m. and refreshments. Free. Square House Museum, 1 Purchase Street. 967-7588.

TARRYTOWN -- Strawberry festival, featuring music, craft boutique, tour of museum and strawberry shortcake with homemade whipped cream. Today from 2 to 5 p.m. Rain or shine. Tickets: $7.50. Historical Society, Serving Sleepy Hollow and Tarrytown, 1 Grove Street. 631-8374.
ON THE TOWNS
